data.text: Any Thoughts on Bicycle Touring with Aero Bars?

Hi all. Just wondering about touring with aero bars? Thinking it would give hand position options on longer rides (I know some ultra cyclists use them), and help with securing gear to the handlebars. Speed/aerodynamics isn't really my concern!!
May not be relevant but I only tour with bull horn bars. It’s way better
data.author: Dahni Beddo

data.text: Just put some on mine. Really enjoying them. I’ve struggled with numb hands and sore wrists. They have really helped with that. Also allows me to relieve my back a bit too. Can’t see me ever taking them off and very tempted to put some on my road bike now.
data.author: Hugh Robinson

data.text: Yeah - I’ve got some too for exactly the same reason.
data.author: Tony Allen

data.text: I used to have them, but took them off eventually. They give you an extra option for positioning, and do help relieve the wrists. But so does stopping and stretching. Useful against a strong headwind - I've noticed they give you a gears' worth of an advantage. Also, surprisingly, it's warmer on them because you block the wind with your shoulders rather than taking it in the torso. So generally positive, but mostly if you're trying to go fast and/or non-stop. I just take a break when the wrists get tired.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Started using some this year. Using ones with 40mm spacers that raise them up by, we'll 40cm. This allows you to still put hands on tops of your handle bar and doesn't drop you too far into full aero position, which would be too uncomfortable. I use them on the longer flatter rides, really helps with an alternative position and gives your hands/wrists a rest.
data.author: Alan Fletcher

data.text: Touring Made Eaiser
data.author: Larry Gowar

data.text: The main advantage is that you can take almost all your weight of the saddle and dance on the pedals allowing massive amounts of watt energy to be transferred into the pedals on both the push down and pull up
data.author: Robert Draycott

data.text: I bought some with the idea of doing this but they take up a lot of room on my (small sized) 'bars leaving me limited room foe my hands to ride on the tops... for luggage I've bought some bar risers instead .

data.text: most people ride on bars near brake hoods or on brake hoods so they can react to braking.
